pullRequest.body:
Lemmas around this were a mess, throth in terms of names, statement and location. This PR standardises everything to be in `Algebra.BigOperators.Basic` and changes the lemmas to take in `InjOn` and `SurjOn` assumptions where possible (and where impossible make sure the hypotheses are taken in the correct order) and moves the equality of functions hypothesis last.

Also add a few lemmas that help fix downstream uses by golfing.

From LeanAPAP and LeanCamCombi

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: !bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/4baff9ed-6f3c-446a-8d7c-6282335f22d0) for commit a7371c4cc2e5b6aaba651edec8a0ad0bcf00ee38.
The entire run failed.
Found no significant differences.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/3ef42229-39fa-435d-b03d-e4d5222b4f75) for commit 20893700ddc23136ce0c1a3aeaed494a16b4fe8b.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/42d4f7d9-d42e-4a4f-a8d7-5cce01841d7f/to/3ef42229-39fa-435d-b03d-e4d5222b4f75) against commit 7a302eb97c8a48fef146f33f55eb00fc7a5541e3:
```diff
  Benchmark                        Metric         Change
  ======================================================
- ~Mathlib.Probability.StrongLaw   instructions    10.3%
```

`Probability.StrongLaw` basically proves the same lemma about swapping sums three times and I've fixed everything by sticking in a lot of `aesop` calls. I will try to find a generalisation of `sum_Ico_Ico_comm` that works for all three applications, but I'm willing to call that out of scope for this PR.
bors d+

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7341426056/job/19989089000)
Canceled.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7341843617/job/19990199442)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7341843617/job/19990199263)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7341843617/job/19990199170)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∏ j, ∏ i in s.filter fun i ↦ g i = j, f i = ∏ i in s, f i := ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ∏ j, ∏ _i in s.filter fun i ↦ g i = j, f j = ∏ i in s, f (g i) := ```
What does the `n` in `nbij` stand for?
**N**on-dependent. Bhavik came up with this name, we both don't like it. Do you have any suggestion?
I'm inclined to go with `prod_bij'`. And just explain the difference in the docstrings using cross-refs. "See `foo_bar` for a (non)dependent variant."
`prod_bij'` already exists! It's the version which takes in two functions that are inverse to each other on the finsets.

Aha... arguably the name of that lemma should be closer to `equiv` than to `bij`. But maybe that's out of scope for this PR.

So let's go for `nbij` for now. But please explain the name in the docstrings.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: Better lemmas for transferring finite sums along equivalences

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory.SmoothNumbers): add `{smooth|rough}NumbersUpTo` and some API
